text: In statistics, the folded-t and half-t distributions are derived from Student's t-distribution by taking the absolute values of variates. This is analogous to the folded-normal and the half-normal statistical distributions being derived from the normal distribution. ==Definitions== The folded non- standardized t distribution is the distribution of the absolute value of the non-standardized t distribution with u degrees of freedom; its probability density function is given by: :g\left(x\right)\;=\;\frac{\Gamma\left(\frac{ u+1}{2}\right)}{\Gamma\left(\frac{ u}{2}\right)\sqrt{ u\pi\sigma^2}}\left\lbrace \left[1+\frac{1}{ u}\frac{\left(x-\mu\right)^2}{\sigma^2}\right]^{-\frac{ u+1}{2}}+\left[1+\frac{1}{ u}\frac{\left(x+\mu\right)^2}{\sigma^2}\right]^{-\frac{ u+1}{2}} \right\rbrace \qquad(\mbox{for}\quad x \geq 0). The half-t distribution results as the special case of \mu=0, and the standardized version as the special case of \sigma=1. If \mu=0, the folded-t distribution reduces to the special case of the half-t distribution. Its probability density function then simplifies to :g\left(x\right)\;=\;\frac{2\;\Gamma\left(\frac{ u+1}{2}\right)}{\Gamma\left(\frac{ u}{2}\right)\sqrt{ u\pi\sigma^2}} \left(1+\frac{1}{ u}\frac{x^2}{\sigma^2}\right)^{-\frac{ u+1}{2}} \qquad(\mbox{for}\quad x \geq 0). The half-t distribution's first two moments (expectation and variance) are given by: :\operatorname{E}[X]\;=\;2\sigma\sqrt{\frac{ u}{\pi}}\frac{\Gamma(\frac{ u+1}{2})}{\Gamma(\frac{ u}{2})\,( u-1)} \qquad\mbox{for}\quad u > 1, and :\operatorname{Var}(X)\;=\;\sigma^2\left(\frac{ u}{ u-2}-\frac{4 u}{\pi( u-1)^2}\left(\frac{\Gamma(\frac{ u+1}{2})}{\Gamma(\frac{ u}{2})}\right)^2\right) \qquad\mbox{for}\quad u > 2. == Relation to other distributions== Folded-t and half-t generalize the folded normal and half-normal distributions by allowing for finite degrees-of-freedom (the normal analogues constitute the limiting cases of infinite degrees-of-freedom). Since the Cauchy distribution constitutes the special case of a Student-t distribution with one degree of freedom, the families of folded and half-t distributions include the folded Cauchy and half-Cauchy distributions for u=1. ==See also== * Cauchy distribution * folded normal distribution * half-normal distribution * normal distribution * Student-t distribution == References == ==Further reading== * * * * ==External links== * Functions to evaluate half-t distributions are available in several R packages, e.g. .
